properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wet and windy weekend for Coastal BC Heavy rain and strong winds are in store for coastal communities of BC this weekend. An atmospheric river will take aim at northern Vancouver Island and the Central Coast beginning early Saturday morning delivering heavy rain and mild conditions until mid-day Sunday. The heaviest rainfall is expected along the west side of Vancouver Island and coastal communities of the Central Coast. The details remain to be finalized however; total rainfall amounts in excess of 100 mm are likely over these areas. Given the tropical origin of the atmospheric river, freezing levels will be on the rise upwards of 3000 metres for the South Coast and close to 2500 metres for the North Coast. The mild air will result in rain at almost all elevations. High runoff and rising river levels are likely through the weekend. Mountainous regions further south including the Sunshine Coast, Howe Sound and the North Shore Mountains will also see significant rainfall, potentially exceeding the rainfall warning criteria of 50 mm in 24 hours. In addition to the heavy rain, strong winds will also accompany the moisture-laden system. Exposed coastal communities along West Vancouver Island, the Central and North Coasts will likely experience wind gusts in excess of 90km/h on Saturday morning. The public is encouraged to monitor potential rainfall and wind warnings from Environment and Climate Change Canada as well as potential high streamflow advisories or flood watches from the BC River Forecast Centre. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-16T03:15:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-15T11:16:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0706168898.2019
Area: North Vancouver Island, West Vancouver Island, Central Coast - coastal sections, Central Coast - inland sections, Sunshine Coast - Gibsons to Earls Cove, Sunshine Coast - Saltery Bay to Powell River, Howe Sound, Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge, North Coast - inland including Kitimat

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning. Brief but intense bands of snow, associated with a fast moving cold front will pass through the area this morning. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 5 cm are possible by sunrise along with gusty winds. Motorists should be prepared for deteriorating driving conditions including accumulating snow and low visibility due to blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow and local snow squalls this morning. Lake effect flurries and local snow squalls are expected to taper off late this morning. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are possible. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow tonight into early Friday morning. Strong westerly winds up to 70 km/h combined with fresh snow will reduce visibility to near zero at times through Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning. Brief but intense bands of snow, associated with a fast moving cold front will pass through the area after sunrise. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 cm are possible along with gusty winds. Motorists should be prepared for deteriorating driving conditions including accumulating snow and low visibility due to blowing snow. In the wake of the cold front, temperatures will drop several degrees in just a few hours. Any snow that may have melted on roads and other surfaces could freeze producing icy and slippery conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 90 to 110 km/h. Locations: Hopedale, Postville and Makkovik. Time span: Friday evening until Saturday night. Remarks: Snow will begin Friday evening and become heavy, at times, on Saturday. Very strong northwesterly winds will develop on Saturday and cause near zero visibility in blowing snow. The snow is expected to taper off around midnight Saturday night and winds will begin to ease by Sunday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-15T19:24:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-15T03:25:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2815736633.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, blowing snow and strong northwesterly winds expected Saturday. Total Snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 100 to 120 km/h. Locations: along the coast from Natuashish to Makkovik. Time span: beginning overnight tonight and lasting until Saturday evening or early Sunday. Remarks: Snow will begin this evening before strong northwesterly winds develop overnight to cause poor visibility in snow and blowing snow. Conditions will persist for most areas through most of Saturday, diminishing in the Natuashish area by evening, and in the Makkovik area by early Sunday morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-16T01:16:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-15T09:17:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3956966775.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity, Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and strong winds are expected. Total snowfall: 2 to 5 cm, except possibly exceeding 15 cm in the Natuashish area. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 100 km/h. Locations: Nain to Natuashish. Time span: Friday evening until Saturday evening. Remarks: Snow will begin Friday evening, and will likely become heavy at times in the Natuashish area by early Saturday. Strong northwesterly winds will develop and cause poor visibility in blowing snow over all areas during the day on Saturday. Conditions are expected to improve again Saturday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions will continue in the Dempster region. Wind gusts exceeding 100 km/h near the Richardson Mountains with falling snow will produce near zero visibility in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions will abate overnight as winds subside to 30 to 50 km/h. ### Road closures are likely. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-15T18:34:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-15T02:35:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2561858092.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low-pressure system passing near the Belcher Islands will bring intense northwesterly winds gusting up to 100 kilometres per hour on Friday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-15T18:59:22-00:00

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: locally 100 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: late this afternoon and early this evening. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. properties.Summary:

Time span: Saturday afternoon into Saturday evening. Remarks: A period of strong northwesterly winds is expected, with the highest gusts anticipated along exposed areas of the coast. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected this morning. Strong northwesterly winds up to 70 km/h will develop this morning during the passage of a cold front. Fresh snow combined with these winds will reduce visibility to near zero at times through the morning hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain has developed along a line extending from Peace River southwards to Hinton Prairie and is expected to move towards the east-northeast this morning. Warnings may need to be expanded today as the freezing rain transitions eastwards. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
